Expectation1: Follow safety and hygiene protocols at all times.
Situation1: They are expected to strictly follow all safety rules, such as using gloves, masks, and proper sanitizers for every task.
Expectation2: Observe kosher dietary laws in daily meals
Situation2: At a communal event, the catered dishes lack certification and substituting food would be difficult.
Story: I stood in the staff break room, the smell of food from the communal event drifting in. My supervisor handed me a plate, reminding me to eat before my next cleaning round. I glanced at the spread—none of it had kosher certification, and I couldn’t be sure how it was prepared. My stomach rumbled, but I hesitated. As a housekeeping cleaner, I was expected to keep up my energy and follow all safety protocols, especially now with the extra shifts. Skipping meals could make me lightheaded, and I needed to be alert, careful with chemicals and equipment. But as a Jew, I was raised to observe kosher laws, to be mindful of what I eat, even when it’s hard. The expectation to respect my faith pressed against the practical need to do my job well. I felt the weight of both roles, the demands of my work and my beliefs pulling me in opposite directions, and I stood there, plate in hand, unsure what to do next.
